items.content: The Republican president has repeatedly called scrutiny over his own relationship with Epstein a 'Democratic hoax'.

items.title: Trump calls for Epstein's 'ties' with Bill Clinton and other Democrats to be investigated
items.standfirst: Donald Trump said he will ask the Justice Department to investigate Jeffrey Epstein's alleged ties to former US president Bill Clinton and other prominent Democrats.
items.content: Donald Trump said he will ask the Justice Department to investigate Jeffrey Epstein's alleged ties to former US president Bill Clinton and other prominent Democrats.

items.title: Trump shifts focus to Epstein’s ties with Democrats as new emails scrutiny grows
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Friday called on the Justice Department and FBI to probe Jeffrey Epstein’s alleged ties to prominent Democrats including former president Bill Clinton and former Treasury secretary Larry Summers. The move comes as questions grow over Trump’s own long-standing relationship with Epstein and lawmakers prepare a vote to force disclosure.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Friday called on the Justice Department and FBI to probe Jeffrey Epstein’s alleged ties to prominent Democrats including former president Bill Clinton and former Treasury secretary Larry Summers. The move comes as questions grow over Trump’s own long-standing relationship with Epstein and lawmakers prepare a vote to force disclosure.

ai_summary: Trump requested the Justice Department probe Jeffrey Epstein's ties to Democrats and banks.
Democrats accuse Trump of using the Justice Department to deflect from his Epstein relationship.
New emails released by the House Oversight Committee resurfaced Trump's Epstein ties.
Trump has called scrutiny of his Epstein relationship a "Democratic hoax".
Several news outlets reported on Trump's request for an investigation.

items.content: The US president confirmed he intends to sue the broadcaster for at least $1bn over the Panorama edit of a 2021 speech.

items.content: President Trump had threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion over a program it aired in 2024 about the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol.

items.title: Trump confirms he'll sue BBC for up to $5 billion
items.standfirst: United States President Donald Trump confirmed he would take legal action against the BBC, seeking damages "anywhere between $1 billion and $5 billion, probably sometime next week." More to come......
items.content: United States President Donald Trump confirmed he would take legal action against the BBC, seeking damages "anywhere between $1 billion and $5 billion, probably sometime next week." More to come......

items.title: BBC apologises to Trump over speech edit but rejects defamation claim
items.standfirst: The BBC sent a personal apology to US President Donald Trump on Thursday but said there was no legal basis for him to sue the public broadcaster over a documentary his lawyers called defamatory.
items.content: The BBC sent a personal apology to US President Donald Trump on Thursday but said there was no legal basis for him to sue the public broadcaster over a documentary his lawyers called defamatory.

items.title: BBC accused of bias after airing misleading edit of Trump speech
items.standfirst: Britain's BBC has apologised to US President Donald Trump after airing a misleading edit of his speech from January 6, 2021, moments before the US Capitol riot. British politicians and the press have both attacked and defended the national broadcaster amid allegations of partiality. This week's guest on FRANCE 24's media show Scoop is Dr. Tom Mills, a senior lecturer in sociology at Aston University and the author of "The BBC: Myth of a Public Service".
items.content: Britain's BBC has apologised to US President Donald Trump after airing a misleading edit of his speech from January 6, 2021, moments before the US Capitol riot. British politicians and the press have both attacked and defended the national broadcaster amid allegations of partiality. This week's guest on FRANCE 24's media show Scoop is Dr. Tom Mills, a senior lecturer in sociology at Aston University and the author of "The BBC: Myth of a Public Service".

ai_summary: Trump plans to sue the BBC for at least $1 billion over a Panorama edit.
The BBC apologized to Trump for editing his January 6 speech in a documentary.
The BBC edited Trump's speech from January 6, 2021, before the Capitol riot.
The BBC rejected a defamation claim from Trump, despite the apology.
Trump is seeking damages between $1 billion and $5 billion from the BBC.

items.title: Trump reverses course and cuts tariffs on US food imports
items.standfirst: Order exempting coffee, beef, bananas and other items comes as White House fights off concerns about rising costsPeople in the US: how are your holiday shopping plans being affected by Trump’s tariffs and the cost of living?Donald Trump moved to lower tariffs on food imports, including beef, tomatoes, coffee and bananas, in an executive order on Friday as the White House fights off growing concerns about rising costs.The new exemptions take effect retroactively at midnight on Thursday and mark a sharp reversal for Trump, who has long insisted that his import duties are not fueling inflation. They come after a string of victories for Democrats in state and local elections in Virginia, New Jersey and New York City, where affordability was a key topic. Continue reading...
items.content: Order exempting coffee, beef, bananas and other items comes as White House fights off concerns about rising costsPeople in the US: how are your holiday shopping plans being affected by Trump’s tariffs and the cost of living?Donald Trump moved to lower tariffs on food imports, including beef, tomatoes, coffee and bananas, in an executive order on Friday as the White House fights off growing concerns about rising costs.The new exemptions take effect retroactively at midnight on Thursday and mark a sharp reversal for Trump, who has long insisted that his import duties are not fueling inflation. They come after a string of victories for Democrats in state and local elections in Virginia, New Jersey and New York City, where affordability was a key topic. Continue reading...

items.title: People in the US: how are your holiday shopping plans being affected by Trump’s tariffs and the cost of living?
items.standfirst: We want to hear from people in the US about how Donald Trump’s economic policies may be affecting their plans for holiday shoppingWe’d like to find out more about your holiday spending plans this year. The New York Times reported on Friday that the Trump administration is pivoting to an affordability message and considering lowering some tariffs rates.The administration has floated policies that would lower prices for coffee and fruit, spoken about a 50-year mortgage proposal, and Trump has mused on social media about giving Americans $2,000 funded by tariff revenue. Continue reading...
items.content: We want to hear from people in the US about how Donald Trump’s economic policies may be affecting their plans for holiday shoppingWe’d like to find out more about your holiday spending plans this year. The New York Times reported on Friday that the Trump administration is pivoting to an affordability message and considering lowering some tariffs rates.The administration has floated policies that would lower prices for coffee and fruit, spoken about a 50-year mortgage proposal, and Trump has mused on social media about giving Americans $2,000 funded by tariff revenue. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Trump removed tariffs on beef, coffee, and tropical fruits.
The move is a reversal of Trump's previous tariff policies.
The tariff cuts are intended to address rising consumer prices.
The White House announced the exemption of certain agricultural products.
Trump's actions follow pressure to lower grocery store prices.

items.title: Judge to approve $7bn settlement with OxyContin maker that requires Sackler family members to pay victims
items.standfirst: Deal would also require multibillionaire family to give up ownership of the Connecticut-based firmA federal bankruptcy court judge on Friday said he would approve OxyContin-maker Purdue Pharma’s latest deal to settle thousands of lawsuits over the toll of opioids that includes some money for thousands of victims of the epidemic.The deal overseen by US bankruptcy judge Sean Lane would require some of the multibillionaire members of the semi-reclusive Sackler family who own the company to contribute up to $7bn and give up ownership of the Connecticut-based firm. Continue reading...
items.content: Deal would also require multibillionaire family to give up ownership of the Connecticut-based firmA federal bankruptcy court judge on Friday said he would approve OxyContin-maker Purdue Pharma’s latest deal to settle thousands of lawsuits over the toll of opioids that includes some money for thousands of victims of the epidemic.The deal overseen by US bankruptcy judge Sean Lane would require some of the multibillionaire members of the semi-reclusive Sackler family who own the company to contribute up to $7bn and give up ownership of the Connecticut-based firm. Continue reading...

The Sackler family will contribute up to $7 billion.
The Sackler family will give up ownership of Purdue Pharma.

clusters.title: Judge finds BHP Group liable in dam collapse that led to Brazil’s worst environmental disaster
clusters.neutral_headline: Judge Finds BHP Group Liable in Dam Collapse

items.title: Judge finds BHP Group liable in dam collapse that led to Brazil’s worst environmental disaster
items.standfirst: A London judge ruled Friday that global mining company BHP Group is liable in Brazil’s worst environmental disaster when a dam collapse a decade ago unleashed tons of toxic waste into a major river, killing 19 people and devastating villages downstream.
items.content: A London judge ruled Friday that global mining company BHP Group is liable in Brazil’s worst environmental disaster when a dam collapse a decade ago unleashed tons of toxic waste into a major river, killing 19 people and devastating villages downstream.

items.title: UK court finds mining firm liable for Brazil's worst environmental disaster
items.standfirst: The 2015 dam collapse killed 19 people, polluted a river and destroyed hundreds of homes.
items.content: The 2015 dam collapse killed 19 people, polluted a river and destroyed hundreds of homes.

items.title: Mining firm BHP found liable in UK for disastrous Brazilian dam collapse
items.standfirst: About 600,000 people seeking compensation a decade on from disaster that killed 19 and devastated villagesThe global mining company BHP Group has been found liable for the deadly 2015 collapse of a Brazilian dam, in a landmark ruling that could pave the way for a multibillion-dollar payout.The high court in London on Friday, Mrs Justice O’Farrell ruled that BHP was responsible for the collapse of the Fundão dam in Mariana despite not owning the dam at the time. Continue reading...
items.content: About 600,000 people seeking compensation a decade on from disaster that killed 19 and devastated villagesThe global mining company BHP Group has been found liable for the deadly 2015 collapse of a Brazilian dam, in a landmark ruling that could pave the way for a multibillion-dollar payout.The high court in London on Friday, Mrs Justice O’Farrell ruled that BHP was responsible for the collapse of the Fundão dam in Mariana despite not owning the dam at the time. Continue reading...

items.title: Mining giant held liable for deadly dam collapse that unleashed avalanche of toxic waste
items.standfirst: A judge has ruled that a company can be held liable for a dam collapse which devastated indigenous communities in Brazil and became the country's worst environmental catastrophe.
items.content: A judge has ruled that a company can be held liable for a dam collapse which devastated indigenous communities in Brazil and became the country's worst environmental catastrophe.

ai_summary: A UK court found BHP Group liable for the 2015 Brazilian dam collapse.
The dam collapse was Brazil's worst environmental disaster.
The collapse killed 19 people and devastated villages.
The ruling could lead to a multibillion-dollar payout.
The court ruled BHP was responsible for the dam's collapse.

clusters.title: Man who grabbed Ariana Grande at Wicked sequel premiere charged
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Charged After Grabbing Ariana Grande

items.title: Man who grabbed Ariana Grande at Wicked sequel premiere charged
items.standfirst: Footage shows the man jumping the red carpet barricade of the Singapore premiere of Wicked: For Good, then rushing towards and embracing the starA court in Singapore has charged a man who grabbed Ariana Grande at a premiere of Wicked: For Good on Thursday night with being a public nuisance.Video footage shows Johnson Wen jumping over a barricade at Universal Studios Singapore and rushing at Grande on the red carpet. Grande’s co-star Cynthia Erivo immediately jumped in to help protect her and Wen was moved away. Continue reading...

Grande’s co-star Cynthia Erivo immediately jumped in to help protect her and Wen was moved away. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Chinese astronauts return to earth after spacecraft damaged by space debris
clusters.neutral_headline: Chinese Astronauts Return to Earth

items.title: Chinese astronauts return to earth after spacecraft damaged by space debris
items.standfirst: A three-person crew stranded at China’s space station after their spacecraft was apparently hit by space debris are to return Friday using the craft that brought their replacement crew.
items.content: A three-person crew stranded at China’s space station after their spacecraft was apparently hit by space debris are to return Friday using the craft that brought their replacement crew.

clusters.title: 'Work, work, work!' Japan's new PM under fire for asking staff to come in at 3am
clusters.neutral_headline: Japan PM Under Fire for Early Morning Meetings

items.title: 'Work, work, work!' Japan's new PM under fire for asking staff to come in at 3am
items.standfirst: When she was elected head of Japan's ruling party, Sanae Takaichi declared that she had abandoned the term "work-life balance" and asked fellow party members to "work like a horse". A month into office, the country's first female prime minister appears to have put her words into action. She told parliament that she was only sleeping two to four hours at night, a few days after organising a 3am staff meeting. In a country plagued by a culture of overwork, this hasn't gone down well.
items.content: When she was elected head of Japan's ruling party, Sanae Takaichi declared that she had abandoned the term "work-life balance" and asked fellow party members to "work like a horse". A month into office, the country's first female prime minister appears to have put her words into action. She told parliament that she was only sleeping two to four hours at night, a few days after organising a 3am staff meeting. In a country plagued by a culture of overwork, this hasn't gone down well.

items.title: Two hours a night: Japan PM’s sleep schedule prompts concerns about work-life balance
items.standfirst: Takaichi caused a stir last week after she summoned aides to her office for a 3am meeting to prepare for a budget committee hearingJapan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, has said she gets by on just two to four hours sleep a night – prompting concern over her commitment to a better work-life balance among the country’s fatigued employees.Pointing to the bags beneath her eyes, Takaichi told MPs that she survives on minimal sleep – a habit she shares with her political hero Margaret Thatcher – after being asked how she would tackle Japan’s notoriously long working hours. Continue reading...
items.content: Takaichi caused a stir last week after she summoned aides to her office for a 3am meeting to prepare for a budget committee hearingJapan’s prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, has said she gets by on just two to four hours sleep a night – prompting concern over her commitment to a better work-life balance among the country’s fatigued employees.Pointing to the bags beneath her eyes, Takaichi told MPs that she survives on minimal sleep – a habit she shares with her political hero Margaret Thatcher – after being asked how she would tackle Japan’s notoriously long working hours. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Japan's PM is criticized for asking staff to work at 3 AM.
She said she abandoned the term "work-life balance".
She sleeps only two to four hours a night.
This has caused concern in Japan.
The PM organized a 3 AM staff meeting.
